China will only be emboldened by the Biden administration’s failure to hold them to account, and it breaks the hearts of countless families who lost loved ones to this China-originated pandemic for the President to fail to recognize this.
His message tonight was one of threats of more lockdowns, not of unity, which is not the direction this country needs and wants to go.
He NEVER ascribed responsibility to the nation that unleashed this virus and has taken over half a million US lives — more than the World Wars and Vietnam combined.
Tonight, @POTUS Biden showed no grace or appreciation for the leadership that led to Operation Warp Speed and the development of a safe and effective vaccine.

As former U.S. Ambassador to Japan, I had the opportunity to visit communities that were indelibly marked by that tragic day, but I also got to see firsthand the progress, the resilience, and the incredible spirit of the Japanese people.

The Hagerty-Coons resolution mourns the loss of life, sends condolences to the families of the victims, expresses commitment to the survivors, and commends the Japanese government’s ongoing revitalization efforts.

Today, I introduced a resolution with @ChrisCoons in observance of the 10th anniversary of the March 11, 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwPAOfTXMAMoLvI.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwPAOewWgAEE-y9.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwPAOeyW8AAmTVJ.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwPAOfVWEAA40ZW.jpg

We must act with a sense of urgency to better defend our nation, from federal and state networks, to our large corporations and main street small businesses, to every American, in cyber space. If we fail to rise to the moment, we will soon regret it.

Over the last year, @SenAngusKing and I have spent a lot of time referring to Solarium as a 9/11 Commission before 9/11. But the past few months have challenged this framing. The cyber disruption is already here, and it is happening on a near daily basis.

We need to explore how we can provide liability protections for companies to respond in real time against cyberattacks while doubling down on Solarium recommendations to expand federal network defense and public-private collaboration.

Yet these steps will only help if we action them. We need nominations for the National Cyber Director and CISA Director yesterday. We need a declaratory policy when it comes cyberattacks, and we need to signal that we will enforce it ruthlessly.

Thanks to the CSC's tireless efforts and bipartisan collaboration on both sides of the Hill, the FY 21 NDAA was the most significant cyber legislation in US history. We created the National Cyber Director, strengthened CISA, and took steps to ensure continuity of our economy.

Since then, the US has experienced not only the pandemic, but two catastrophic cyberattacks. As we learn more about the recent Microsoft Exchange attacks, I am increasingly concerned about the damage, especially since criminal groups can exploit this vulnerability.

THREAD ➡️ One year ago today, the @CyberSolarium unveiled its recommendations on Capitol Hill. Little did we know at the time how cyber would become even more important in our day to day lives (or that it would be our last chance to gather in person in the foreseeable future).

I am immensely proud to have supported this bill to deliver help to Maine people in need, and stand ready to continue working with my colleagues and the White House to take any additional action that is needed to beat this pandemic.

The American people agree that American Rescue Plan is exactly the bill we need to meet this moment, with recent polling showing that 77% of the American public supports this plan, including 6 in 10 Republicans. This rare consensus reflects the immense need being felt by so many.

…stimulus checks, funding to aid small businesses, a dedicated fund for restaurants, additional resources for school districts, increased support for working families and historic investments to expand broadband access and close the digital divide.

The pandemic has attacked our economy, strained working families, endangered small businesses, and exacerbated longstanding inequalities that have been left unaddressed for decades. The American Rescue Plan confronts these challenges through extended unemployment insurance...

This package will address the ongoing public health emergency by providing ample funding to support vaccination, testing, tracing, and other key medical needs that are required to control this virus. But as all Americans know, this crisis did not only affect our nation’s health.

Over the past year, COVID-19 has killed more than 500,000 Americans and exacted a devastating toll on our economy. The #AmericanRescueAct is just the start of the bold policies and big, structural changes that Congress can make for working families. You bet I’m in this fight to build opportunity for all of our families.

There’s a lot of other important pieces in this relief bill for Massachusetts. Stimulus and unemployment checks. Expansion of the Child Tax Credit and Earned Income Tax Credit. LIHEAP funding. SNAP benefits and school meal funding. It's a long bill full of great stuff.

Our mass transit systems are critical infrastructure for our cities and towns, but COVID has created budget nightmares. Massachusetts will receive over $1 billion in relief for our mass transit systems for operating expenses, payroll costs, and protective equipment.

Restaurants have been crushed all year, and this bill has some real support. The $25 billion Restaurant Revitalization Fund helps small restaurant owners in Massachusetts and nationwide. And it expands the PPP program by $7.25 billion with more flexibility and forgiveness.

With millions of people still out of work during this crisis, cash-strapped families have struggled to keep a roof over their heads. Massachusetts will receive $362 million in emergency rental assistance to help stop a wave of evictions.

To help our schools safely reopen, the relief bill includes $1.8 billion in Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief funding for Massachusetts. And for our older students, it has $825 million for MA colleges, including millions to help students with financial aid grants.

We need child care for parents to go back to work – and I fought for $50 billion in child care funding nationwide. Massachusetts is going to see $512 million to support child care providers and help families afford care, and $13.6 million for Head Start.

Our state and local governments had to pick up the tab when Trump didn't come up with a federal plan to fight this pandemic. The relief bill has $8.1 billion for Massachusetts state and local government funding with much more flexibility than the CARES Act.

The #AmericanRescueAct is a historic piece of legislation for our country’s recovery from this pandemic and economic crisis. But I want to take a moment to mention some of the big wins we fought for to help families back home in Massachusetts:

Today we remember the family, friends, and neighbors we loved – and we search for a way to settle this loss in our hearts. We need each other more than ever, working together to build tomorrow, and the next day, and the next day, with opportunities for better days ahead.

On this one-year anniversary, I’m optimistic about the future. We have vaccines and a strong relief package on the way. The numbers are looking better. But our hearts still hurt from everything and everyone that this pandemic has stolen from us.

And our essential workers – including grocery store workers, farm workers, warehouse workers, meatpacking workers, restaurant workers, and delivery workers – have risked their health in the scariest conditions to keep us safe and fed. We’re in their debt.

Our doctors, nurses, hospital staff, public health experts and scientists have worked around the clock, one grueling day after another, to stop the virus. They’ve carried the weight of the world on their shoulders – our hopes and our heartbreak. They deserve our thanks every day.

When the WHO declared COVID-19 a global pandemic one year ago today, our country didn’t know what was around the corner. Over half a million lives lost. Tens of millions sick. Jobs gone and businesses shuttered. Unthinkable grief without hugs for comfort.

The #CharlestonLoophole allows someone to purchase a firearm 3 days after a background check begins, even if it hasn’t been completed, which allowed almost 3,000 guns to be sold to prohibited purchasers in 2019.

It's been an incredibly difficult year, and the American Rescue Plan will provide an array of tools needed to provide relief and combat the pandemic.

This package is going to deliver on tax credits, affordable health care, stimulus checks and more: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/10/us/politics/biden-stimulus-middle-class-benefits.html

That's why I authored the 911 Diversion to Unarmed Personnel Act to support programs that enable 911 call dispatchers to direct nonviolent calls toward unarmed, specialized responders who can connect people with the care they need. 

Read more here: 
https://adamsmith.house.gov/press-releases?id=48F0683B-1928-474E-829F-AF751E2DF17C
These programs reduce violent and hostile encounters, help restore trust between law enforcement and community members, and provide better services and care for public safety.

Community-based public safety programs have been incredibly successful in responding to nonviolent 911 calls. Instead of sending police to a behavioral health crisis, specialized service providers like social workers, medical professionals & peer support counselors would respond.

Addressing systemic racism & restructuring law enforcement’s approach to public safety must recognize the range of urgent needs that are best addressed without police involvement in a holistic, equitable way that centers on getting individuals the resources & services they need.

It’s abundantly clear that we need to fundamentally reimagine public safety and what law enforcement looks like in our country.

Too often, law enforcement officers are tasked with responding to situations they are neither trained nor equipped to handle.
